content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes members from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Additionally, steering committees are appointed, and ex officio members are included. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference establishes advisory committees and includes ex officio members. A pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan must be published within a year, clarifying duties and suggesting a timetable for activities. The Plan developed pursuant to this section shall clarify duties, describe funding methods, incorporate environmental management concepts, and include a strategy for water pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Plan developed under this section must include a strategy for water pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, with public review and approval by the Administrator. Upon approval of the Plan developed for water pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, it will be deemed an approved management program and comprehensive conservation plan. Grant assistance may be provided for the development of the Plan, including research, surveys, and technical work. Grants for developing the Plan in the Coeur d'Alene Basin will assist with research, surveys, studies, and technical work. The federal share of grants will not exceed 70% of development costs, with the condition that non-Federal sources provide the remaining share. The Administrator can establish terms and conditions for grant administration. The Coeur d'Alene Basin is defined as the watershed in northern Idaho containing specific water bodies. The Administrator can establish terms and conditions for grant administration in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, defined as a specific watershed in northern Idaho. This section does not affect the jurisdiction or powers of any department or agency of the United States or any State, or any entity related to the Basin created by treaty or memorandum. Appropriations are authorized to the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by developing an integrated geographic information system, converting recording sites to monitoring stations, and establishing additional monitoring sites as needed. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish continuous monitoring stations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin for data collection, including ground water mapping and water quality monitoring. Additionally, a fisheries resources restoration program will be implemented within the basin. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act mandates a fisheries restoration program and wildlife species survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including monitoring endangered species and habitat assessment. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act requires a fisheries restoration program and wildlife species survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The program includes monitoring endangered species, special concern species, and migratory bird populations. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving fishery resources, conducting investigations on their status, and updating surveys of fishery resources and habitats in the basin. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act authorizes the Department of the Interior to conduct investigations and surveys on fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999 to support these activities. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with natural resource trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes creating a geographical information system inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas, and cleaning up mining contaminated sites. The plan involves cleaning up mining contaminated sites, restoring damaged natural resources, implementing stream and river restoration plans, monitoring restored areas, and developing a land management plan in cooperation with various stakeholders. The plan includes documenting restoration effectiveness, addressing residual problems, developing a land management plan with stakeholders, creating a geographical information system, and implementing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans. The plan involves developing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans, monitoring wildlife areas, creating public recreation management plans, and implementing a lake and river information program in the Basin. The plan for the Basin includes developing a lake and river information program to provide public use and health risk information, along with managing public land sites. The Director of the Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, restoration activities, and construction of restoration projects and management facilities. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities such as restoring mining contaminated lands, designing and maintaining restoration projects and management facilities, overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste, implementing a lake and river information program, creating long-term restoration and land management plans, and providing maintenance for restored public lands. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995-2002 to support these activities. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
